Die Winkel bleiben erhalten, aber Längen und Flächeninhalte bleiben
aber im Allgemeinen \emph{nicht} erhalten.


\section[Komplexe Integration]{Kurvenintegrale, Komplexe Integration}

Betrachte wieder Kurve $\gamma:I=\left[a,b\right]\to\Omega\subseteq\mathbb{C}$
($\Omega$ offen) sei stetig und stückweise differenzierbar.

TODO: Abb4

Identifiziere zunächst $\mathbb{C}$ mit $\mathbb{R}^{2}$.

Dann kann man die \emph{Bogenlänge} $L\left(\gamma\right)$ folgendermaßen
einführen:
\begin{align*}
L\left(\gamma\right) & =\int_{a}^{b}\left|\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right|\dd\tau
\end{align*}
(Nehme hier zur Einfachheit an, dass $\gamma$ differenzierbar ist,
sonst stückweise integrieren und Integrale addieren.)

$L\left(\gamma\right)$ soll unabhängig von der Parametrisierung sein.
Rechne dies nach:
\begin{align*}
\tilde{\gamma}\left(t\right) & =\left(\gamma\circ\tau\right)\left(t\right) & \tau:\left[\alpha,\beta\right] & \to\left[a,b\right]
\end{align*}
$\tau$ sei streng monoton steigend und $\tau'\left(t\right)\not=0$
für alle $t\in\left[\alpha,\beta\right]$.
\begin{align*}
\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\left|\tilde{\gamma}'\left(t\right)\right|\dd t & \stackrel{\text{Kettenregel}}{=}\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\bigg|\gamma'\left(t\right)\cdot\underbrace{\frac{\dd\tau}{\dd t}}_{>0}\bigg|\dd t=\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\left|\gamma'\left(t\right)\right|\frac{\dd\tau}{\dd t}\dd t=\\
 & \sr{=}{\text{Substitution}}{t=t\left(\tau\right),\dd t=\frac{\dd t}{\dd\tau}\dd t}\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\left|\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right|\dd\tau=L\left(\gamma\right)
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\frac{\dd\tau}{\dd t}\dd t & =\int_{a}^{b}\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}
Sei nun außerdem $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ stetig (wichtigstes Beispiel:
$f$ holomorph).

Wir wollen \quotedblbase{}$f$ längs $\gamma$ integrieren\textquotedblleft{}:
\begin{align*}
\gamma:\left[a,b\right] & \to\mathbb{C}
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\left|\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right|\dd\tau
\end{align*}
Dies wäre eine Möglichkeit, denn dies ist unabhängig von der Parametrisierung.

In der komplexen Analysis ist das Integral
\begin{align*}
\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}
interessanter, weil keine komplexe Konjugation eingeht.


\subsection{Definition \textmd{(komplexes Integral)}}

Sei $\gamma:\left[a,b\right]\to\Omega\subseteq\mathbb{C}$ stetig
und stückweise differenzierbar und $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ stetig.

Dann heißt
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & :=\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}
das \emph{komplexe Integral} oder \emph{Konturintegral} von $f$ über
$\gamma$.


\subsubsection*{Beachte}

Wir integrieren über eine \emph{reelle Variable} $t\in\left[a,b\right]$,
aber der Integrand ist komplexwertig.

Man kann das auf reellwertige Integrale zurückführen.
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & :=\int_{a}^{b}\text{Re}\left(f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right)\dd\tau+\ii\int_{a}^{b}\text{Im}\left(f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}
Riemann- beziehungsweise Lebesgue-Integral im Reellen.

Insbesondere sieht man:
\begin{align*}
\text{Re}\left(\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z\right) & =\int_{a}^{b}\text{Re}\big(f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\big)\dd\tau\\
 & \not=\int_{\gamma}\text{Re}\left(f\left(z\right)\right)\dd z=\int_{a}^{b}\text{Re}\big(f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\big)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}



\subsection{Satz}

${\displaystyle \int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z}$ ist unabhängig
von der Parametrisierung.


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

Sei $t:\left[\alpha,\beta\right]\to\left[a,b\right]$ streng monoton
steigend, stetig, stückweise differenzierbar.

Dann folgt mit $\tilde{\gamma}\left(\tau\right)=\left(\gamma\circ t\right)\left(\tau\right)$:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\left(f\circ\gamma\circ t\right)\left(\tau\right)\cdot\left(\gamma\circ t\right)'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau & =\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\left(f\circ\gamma\right)\left(t\left(\tau\right)\right)\cdot\gamma'\left(t\left(\tau\right)\right)\frac{\dd t}{\dd\tau}\dd\tau=\\
 & \stackrel{\text{Transformationsformel}}{=}\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\left(f\circ\gamma\right)\left(t\right)\cdot\gamma'\left(t\right)\dd t
\end{align*}
\qqed


\subsection{Beispiel}

\begin{iiilist}

\iii ${\displaystyle f\left(z\right)=\frac{1}{z^{2}}}$, $\gamma:\left[1,2\right]\to\mathbb{C}:t\mapsto t$
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{1}^{2}f\left(\gamma\left(t\right)\right)\gamma'\left(t\right)\dd t=\int_{1}^{2}\frac{1}{t^{2}}\cdot1\dd t=\frac{-1}{t}\bigg|_{1}^{2}=\frac{-1}{2}+1=\frac{1}{2}
\end{align*}


%DATE Fr 23.12.2011

\iii $f\left(z\right)=z^{n},\: n\ge0$\\
Wähle eine Parametrisierung zum Beispiel

\begin{align*}
\gamma_{1}:\left[0,1\right] & \to\mathbb{C}\\
\gamma_{1}\left(\tau\right) & =\tau\left(1+\ii\right)\\
\gamma_{1}'\left(\tau\right) & =\left(1+\ii\right)
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma_{1}}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{0}^{1}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\cdot\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau=\int_{0}^{1}\left(\left(1+\ii\right)\cdot\tau\right)^{n}\cdot\left(1+\ii\right)\dd\tau=\\
 & =\left(1+\ii\right)^{n+1}\cdot\int_{0}^{1}\tau^{n}\dd\tau=\frac{1}{n+1}\cdot\left(1+\ii\right)^{n+1}
\end{align*}
$\gamma_{2}$: Parametrisiere so:
\begin{align*}
\gamma_{2}:\left[0,2\right] & \to\mathbb{C}\\
\gamma\left(\tau\right) & =\begin{cases}
\tau & 0\le\tau\le1\\
\left(1+\left(\tau-1\right)\ii\right) & 1\le\tau\le2
\end{cases}\\
\gamma'\left(\tau\right) & =\begin{cases}
1 & 0<\tau<1\\
\ii & 1<\tau<2
\end{cases}
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma_{2}}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{0}^{1}\tau^{n}\cdot1\dd\tau+\int_{1}^{2}\left(1+\left(\tau-1\right)\cdot\ii\right)^{n}\cdot\ii\dd\tau=\frac{1}{n+1}+\ii\cdot\frac{1}{\left(n+1\right)\ii}\left(1+\left(\tau-1\right)\ii\right)^{n+1}\bigg|_{1}^{2}=\\
 & =\frac{1}{n+1}+\frac{1}{n+1}\left(\left(1+\ii\right)^{n+1}-1\right)=\frac{1}{n+1}\cdot\left(1+\ii\right)^{n+1}
\end{align*}


\end{iiilist}

Der Wert des Integrals ist also für beide Integrationswege gleich.


\subsection{Definition}

Sei $\gamma:\left[0,1\right]\to\mathbb{C}$.

Setze
\begin{align*}
-\gamma & :=\tilde{\gamma}:\left[0,1\right]\to\mathbb{C},\:\tilde{\gamma}\left(\tau\right)=\gamma\left(1-\tau\right)
\end{align*}
also \quotedblbase{}durchlaufe die Kurve rückwärts\textquotedblleft{}.

Sei $\gamma_{1}:\left[a,b\right]\to\mathbb{C}$ und $\gamma_{2}:\left[b,c\right]\to\mathbb{C}$
mit $\gamma_{1}\left(b\right)=\gamma_{2}\left(b\right)$.\\
Setze dann $\gamma_{1}+\gamma_{2}:\left[a,c\right]\to\mathbb{C}$
definiert durch: 
\begin{align*}
\left(\gamma_{1}+\gamma_{2}\right)\left(\tau\right) & =\begin{cases}
\gamma_{1}\left(\tau\right) & \tau\in\left[a,b\right]\\
\gamma_{2}\left(\tau\right) & \tau\in\left[b,c\right]
\end{cases}
\end{align*}



\subsection{Lemma}

\begin{align*}
\int_{-\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =-\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma_{1}+\ldots+\gamma_{n}}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{\gamma_{1}}f\left(z\right)\dd z+\ldots+\int_{\gamma_{n}}f\left(z\right)\dd z
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Beweis}

TODO: Fehlt???


\subsection{Definition}

Setze:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd\overline{z} & =\overline{\int_{\gamma}\overline{f\left(z\right)}\dd z}\\
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd x & =\frac{1}{2}\left(\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z+\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd\overline{z}\right)\\
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd y & =\frac{1}{2\ii}\left(\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z-\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd\overline{z}\right)
\end{align*}
Dann gilt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd x+\ii\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd y
\end{align*}
Also: \quotedblbase{}$\dd z=\dd x+\ii\dd y$\textquotedblleft{}

Etwas ausführlicher:
\begin{align*}
x+\ii y & =z=\gamma\left(\tau\right)\\
x\left(\tau\right) & :=\text{Re}\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right) & \Rightarrow\quad\text{Re}\left(\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right) & =x'\left(\tau\right)\\
y\left(\tau\right) & :=\text{Im}\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right) & \Rightarrow\quad\text{Im}\left(\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right) & =y'\left(\tau\right)\\
\dd x & =x'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau\\
\dd y & =y'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau\\
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd\overline{z} & =\overline{\int_{\gamma}\overline{f\left(z\right)}\dd z}=\int_{a}^{b}\overline{f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)}\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau=\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\overline{\gamma'\left(\tau\right)}\dd\tau\\
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd x & =\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\cdot\underbrace{\text{Re}\left(\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right)}_{=x'\left(\tau\right)}\dd\tau\\
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd y & =\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\cdot\underbrace{\text{Im}\left(\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right)}_{=y'\left(\tau\right)}\dd\tau\\
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd y & =\int_{\gamma}p\dd x+\int_{y}q\dd y
\end{align*}
Später: Setze $p=f$ und $q=\ii f$.


\section[Weg(un)abhängigkeit]{Abhängigkeit vom Integrationsgebiet}

Sei $\Omega\subseteq\mathbb{C}$ offen, $z_{0},z\in\Omega$, $p,q:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$
stetig und wegzusammenhängend.


\subsubsection*{Frage}

Wann gilt folgende Gleichheit?
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma_{1}}\left(p\dd x+q\dd y\right) & =\int_{\gamma_{2}}\left(p\dd x+q\dd y\right)
\end{align*}
Seien $\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}$ zwei differenzierbare Kurven, die $z_{0}$
mit $z$ verbinden.

TODO: Abb2


\subsubsection*{Allgemeine Frage}

Wann ist das Integral unabhängig vom Weg?


\subsection{Theorem\label{sub:Theo-wegunabh=0000E4ngig}}

Das Linienintegral
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}\left(p\dd x+q\dd y\right)
\end{align*}
ist genau dann wegunabhängig, wenn es eine Funktion $U:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$
gibt, so dass:
\begin{align}
p & =\frac{\partial U}{\partial x} & q & =\frac{\partial U}{\partial y}\label{eq:pUxqUy}
\end{align}
(Frobenius, Poincaré, $\ldots$)


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\quotedblbase{}$\Leftarrow$\textquotedblleft{}: Nehme an, dass \eqref{eq:pUxqUy}
gilt, womit folgt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}\left(p\dd x+q\dd y\right) & =\int_{a}^{b}\left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}x'\left(\tau\right)\dd x+\frac{\partial U}{\partial y}y'\left(\tau\right)\dd y\right)=\int_{a}^{b}\frac{\dd}{\dd\tau}\left(U\left(x\left(\tau\right),y\left(\tau\right)\right)\right)=\\
 & =U\left(x\left(b\right),y\left(b\right)\right)-U\left(x\left(a\right),y\left(a\right)\right)=U\left(z\right)-U\left(z_{0}\right)
\end{align*}
Also hängt das Integral tatsächlich nur von Anfangs- und Endpunkt
ab.

\quotedblbase{}$\Rightarrow$\textquotedblleft{}: Nehmen an, dass
das Integral wegunabhängig ist.

$z_{0}=\left(x_{0},y_{0}\right)$ sei fest, während $z=\left(x,y\right)$
variabel.

Wähle als Kurve speziell ein Polygonzug, der parallel zur $x$- oder
$y$-Achse verläuft.

TODO: Abb3

$\gamma$ kann durch einen solchen Polygonzug approximiert werden.

Verwende hierbei, dass $\Omega$ offen und bogenzusammenhängend ist.

Definiere:
\begin{align*}
U\left(x,y\right) & :=\int_{\gamma}\left(p\dd x+q\dd y\right)
\end{align*}
Dies ist wohldefiniert, weil das Integral nach Voraussetzung wegunabhängig
ist.

Berechne ${\displaystyle \frac{\partial U}{\partial x}}$:

Wähle den Polygonzug so, dass er in einer Umgebung von $\left(x,y\right)$
horizontal verläuft.

Dann gilt:
\begin{align*}
U\left(x,y\right) & =\int^{x}p\left(\tilde{x},y\right)\dd\tilde{x}+\text{Konstante}\\
\frac{\partial U}{\partial x} & =p\left(x,y\right)
\end{align*}
Berechne ${\displaystyle \frac{\partial U}{\partial x}}$:

Wähle den Polygonzug so, dass er in einer Umgebung von $\left(x,y\right)$
vertikal verläuft.

Dann gilt:
\begin{align*}
U\left(x,y\right) & =\int^{y}q\left(x,\tilde{y}\right)\dd\tilde{y}+\text{Konstante}\\
\frac{\partial U}{\partial y} & =q\left(x,y\right)
\end{align*}


Also sind die Differentialgleichungen \eqref{eq:pUxqUy} erfüllt.\\
\qqed

Schreibe auch:
\begin{align*}
\int p\dd x+q\dd y & =U\\
p\dd x+q\dd y & =\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}\dd x+\frac{\partial U}{\partial y}\dd y\left(=:\dd U\right)
\end{align*}
Und man nennt $\dd U$ das \emph{totale Differential}.

Das totale Differential ist \emph{exakt}, das heißt es kann in obiger
Form geschrieben werden.

Zurück zum Konturintegral:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int\bigg(\underbrace{f}_{=p}\dd x+\underbrace{\ii f}_{=q}\dd y\bigg)
\end{align*}
Nach Theorem \ref{sub:Theo-wegunabh=0000E4ngig} ist das Konturintegral
genau dann wegunabhängig, wenn ein $F\left(z\right)$ in $\Omega$
existiert, so dass gilt:
\begin{align*}
\frac{\partial F}{\partial x} & =f\left(z\right) & \frac{\partial F}{\partial y} & =\ii f\left(z\right)
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\Rightarrow\quad\frac{\partial F}{\partial x} & =-\ii\frac{\partial F}{\partial y}
\end{align*}
Also erfüllt $F$ die Cauchy-Riemannschen Differentialgleichungen
und $f\left(z\right)=F'\left(z\right)$.


\subsection{Korollar}

$\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z$ ist genau dann wegunabhängig,
wenn es eine holomorphe Funktion $F:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ gibt mit
$f\left(z\right)=F'\left(z\right)$.


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

TODO: ???


\subsection{Satz\label{sub:Satz-PolyOint0}}

Für jedes Polynom $P\left(z\right)$ und jede geschlossene Kurve gilt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}P\left(z\right)\dd z & =0
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\begin{align*}
P\left(z\right) & =a_{n}z^{n}+a_{n-1}z^{n-1}+\ldots+a_{0}\\
Q\left(z\right) & =\frac{a_{n}}{n+1}z^{n+1}+\frac{a_{n-1}}{n}z^{n}+\ldots+a_{0}z
\end{align*}
$Q\left(z\right)$ ist eine holomorphe Stammfunktion, also $Q'\left(z\right)=P\left(z\right)$.\\
\qqed


\section{Das Cauchysche Theorem}

Betrachte das Rechteck $R:a\le x\le b,\, c\le y\le d$. $R\subseteq\Omega\subseteq\mathbb{C}$

TODO: Abb4


\subsubsection*{Frage}

Äquivalente Fragestellungen:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Für welche $f$ ist $\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z$ unabhängig
vom Integrationsweg.
\item Für welche $f$ gibt es eine holomorphe Stammfunktion.
\end{enumerate}
Notwendiges Kriterium:

Falls $f\in C^{1}$ ist, sehen wir, dass für alle geschlossenen Wege
$\gamma$ schon $\oint_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z=0$ nur dann,
wenn $f$ holomorph ist.

TODO: Rest überprüfen $f\in C^{1}$ = holomorph?

$f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ ist holomorph, denn wenn es eine holomorphe
Stammfunktion $F$ gibt, so ist $f=F'$ auch holomorph.

Beginne mit einfachen Integrationswegen und zwar dem Integral längs
des Randes von $R$.

%DATE: Di 10.1.12


\subsection{Theorem\label{sub:Thm-Goursat}}

Ist $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ holomorph, so gilt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\partial R}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =0
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Beweis \textmd{(nach Goursat)}}

Zerlege $R$ in vier kongruente Rechtecke $R^{\left(1\right)},\ldots,R^{\left(4\right)}$.

TODO: Abb5

\begin{align*}
\int_{\partial R}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{\partial R^{\left(1\right)}}f\left(z\right)\dd z+\ldots+\int_{\partial R^{\left(4\right)}}f\left(z\right)\dd z
\end{align*}
Dies gilt, da sich die Integrale längs der \quotedblbase{}inneren
Kanten\textquotedblleft{} gegenseitig aufheben.

Für eines der Rechtecke $R^{\left(k\right)}$ gilt:
\begin{align*}
\left|\int_{\partial R_{1}}f\left(z\right)\dd z\right| & \ge\frac{1}{4}\left|\int_{\partial R}f\left(z\right)\right|
\end{align*}
Dieses nennen wir $R_{1}$.

$ $Wähle nun induktiv Rechtecke $R=R_{0}\supseteq R_{1}\supseteq R_{2}\supseteq\ldots$
so, dass gilt:
\begin{align*}
\left|\eta\left(R_{n}\right)\right| & \ge\frac{1}{4^{n}}\left|\eta\left(R\right)\right|
\end{align*}
Zudem gilt
\begin{align*}
\text{Vol}\left(R_{n}\right) & =4^{-n}\cdot\text{Vol}\left(R\right)
\end{align*}
und die Kantenlängen von $R_{n}$ sind schon $2^{-n}$ mal die Kantenlängen
von $R$.

Seien $z_{n}$ die Mittelpunkte dieser Rechtecke.

Die Folge $\left(z_{n}\right)$ besitzt einen Häufungspunkt $z^{*}\in R$.

TODO: Abb6

Verwende nun ein lokales Argument:

Da $f$ in $z^{*}$ holomorph ist, gilt:
\begin{align*}
f\left(z\right) & =f\left(z^{*}\right)+f'\left(z^{*}\right)\left(z-z^{*}\right)+o\left(\left|z-z^{*}\right|\right)
\end{align*}
Anders ausgedrückt gibt es zu jedem $\varepsilon>0$ ein $\delta>0$,
so dass gilt für alle $z\in B_{\delta}\left(z^{*}\right)\setminus\left\{ z^{*}\right\} $:
\begin{align*}
\left|f\left(z\right)-f\left(z^{*}\right)-f'\left(z^{*}\right)\left(z-z^{*}\right)\right| & <\varepsilon\left|z-z^{*}\right|
\end{align*}
Dies ist ein Polynom, es hat also eine holomorphe Stammfunktion.

Wähle nun $n$ so groß, dass $R_{n}\subseteq B_{\delta}\left(z^{*}\right)$
ist.

Dann gilt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\partial R_{n}}\left[f\left(z^{*}\right)+f'\left(z^{*}\right)\left(z-z^{*}\right)\right] & \stackrel{\ref{sub:Satz-PolyOint0}}{=}0
\end{align*}
Beachte dabei, das wir ein Polynom integrieren.
\begin{align*}
\eta\left(R_{n}\right) & =\int_{\partial R_{n}}f\left(z\right)\dd z=\int_{\partial R_{n}}\left(f\left(z\right)-f\left(z^{*}\right)-f'\left(z^{*}\right)\left(z-z^{*}\right)\right)\dd z
\end{align*}
Also gilt:
\begin{align*}
\left|\eta\left(R_{n}\right)\right| & =\Bigg|\int_{\partial R_{n}}\bigg(\underbrace{f\left(z\right)-f\left(z^{*}\right)-f'\left(z^{*}\right)\left(z-z^{*}\right)}_{\left|\ldots\right|\le\varepsilon\left|z-z^{*}\right|}\bigg)\dd z\Bigg|\le\\
 & \le\varepsilon\Bigg|\int_{\partial R_{n}}\underbrace{\left|z-z^{*}\right|}_{\le2^{-n}\cdot\max\left\{ b-a,d-c\right\} }\dd z\Bigg|\le\\
 & \le\varepsilon\cdot\underbrace{d_{n}}_{\text{Durchmesser von }R_{n}}\cdot\underbrace{L_{n}}_{\text{Umfang von }R}\\
 & \le\varepsilon\cdot4^{-n}\cdot\underbrace{d}_{\text{Durchmesser von }R}\cdot\underbrace{L}_{\text{Umfang von }R_{n}}
\end{align*}
Andererseits gilt:
\begin{align*}
\eta\left(R_{n}\right) & \ge4^{-n}\left|\eta\left(R\right)\right|
\end{align*}


Damit folgt:
\begin{align*}
\eta\left(R\right) & \le\varepsilon\cdot d\cdot L
\end{align*}
Da $\varepsilon$ beliebig ist, folgt $\eta\left(R\right)=0$.\\
\qqed


\subsection{Theorem}

Sei $R'=R\setminus\left\{ \zeta_{1},\ldots,\zeta_{n}\right\} $ ein
Rechteck ohne endlich viele innere Punkte, also $\zeta_{1}\in R^{\circ}$.

Sei $f$ auf $R'$ holomorph und es gelte:
\begin{align*}
\lim_{z\to\zeta_{j}}\left(z-\zeta_{j}\right)f\left(z\right) & =0
\end{align*}
Dann gilt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\partial R}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =0
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Beweis}

Es genügt, einen Ausnahmepunkt zu betrachten, da wir das Rechteck
ansonsten in endlich viele Rechtecke zerlegen können.

TODO: Abb1-b

Nenne den Ausnahmepunkt $\zeta$.

Wähle ein kleines Rechteck $R_{0}$ um $\zeta$ und nenne die restlichen
Rechtecke $R_{i}$.

TODO: Abb2

Weil $f$ in $R_{i}$ für $i\ge1$ holomorph ist, folgt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\partial R_{i}}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =0
\end{align*}
Damit folgt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\partial R}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{\partial R_{0}}f\left(z\right)\dd z
\end{align*}
Nach Voraussetzung können wir zu einem gegebene $\varepsilon>0$ das
Rechteck $R_{0}$ so klein wählen, dass für alle $z\in\partial R_{0}$
gilt:
\begin{align*}
\left|f\left(z\right)\cdot\left(z-\zeta\right)\right| & \le\varepsilon\\
\left|f\left(z\right)\right| & \le\frac{\varepsilon}{\left|z-\zeta\right|}
\end{align*}
Also gilt:
\begin{align*}
\left|\int_{\partial R_{0}}f\left(z\right)\dd z\right| & \le\varepsilon\int_{\partial R_{o}}\frac{\overbrace{\left|\dd z\right|}^{=\left|\gamma'\left(t\right)\right|\dd t}}{\left|z-\zeta\right|}\le\\
 & \le\frac{\varepsilon}{\frac{d_{0}}{4}}\cdot L_{0}=\varepsilon\cdot\frac{4L_{0}}{d_{0}}\le16\varepsilon
\end{align*}
Da $\varepsilon$ beliebig ist, folgt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\partial R}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =0
\end{align*}
\qqed

Verallgemeinere dies nun auf beliebige Kurven in einer Kreisscheibe.


\subsection{Theorem}

Sei $f$ in $\Delta:=B_{R}\left(0\right)\in\mathbb{C}$ holomorph.

Dann gilt für jede geschlossene Kurve $\gamma$ in $\Delta$:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =0
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Beweis}

Sei $z=x+\ii y\in\Delta$.

TODO: Abb3

Wähle ein Rechteck $R$ so, dass die linke untere Ecke der Ursprung
und die rechte obere Ecke $z$ ist.

Nach Theorem \ref{sub:Thm-Goursat} ist
\begin{align*}
\int_{\partial R}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =0
\end{align*}
und deshalb ist
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma_{1}}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{\gamma_{2}}f\left(z\right)\dd z=:F\left(z\right)
\end{align*}
wohldefiniert.

Nach Korollar \ref{asdf}2.9.2 genügt es zu zeigen, dass $F\left(z\right)$
eine holomorphe Stammfunktion von $f$ ist.

Sei $\gamma_{h}$ ein Weg, der $z$ und $z+h$ parallel zur reellen
Achse verbindet.

Sei $\gamma_{g}$ ein Weg, der $z$ und $z+\ii h$ parallel zur imaginären
Achse verbindet.

TODO: Abb4
\begin{align*}
\frac{\partial F}{\partial x} & =\lim_{0\not=h\to0}\int_{\gamma_{h}}f\left(z\right)\dd z=\lim_{0\not=h\to0}\frac{1}{h}\int_{0}^{h}f\left(z+h\right)\cdot\underbrace{\gamma'\left(h\right)}_{=1}\dd h=f\left(z\right)\\
\frac{\partial F}{\partial y} & =\lim_{0\not=h\to0}\frac{1}{h}\left(F\left(z+\ii h\right)-F\left(z\right)\right)=\lim_{0\not=h\to0}\frac{1}{h}\int_{0}^{h}f\left(z+\ii h\right)\cdot\ii\dd h=\ii f\left(z\right)
\end{align*}
Damit sind die Cauchy-Riemannschen Differentialgleichungen erfüllt,
also ist $F$ holomorph und es gilt:
\begin{align*}
F'\left(z\right) & =f\left(z\right)
\end{align*}
\qqed


\subsection{Theorem\label{sub:Thm-OintHolomHebPol}}

Sei $f$ holomorph in $\Delta'=\Delta\setminus\left\{ \zeta_{1},\ldots,\zeta_{n}\right\} $
mit $\zeta_{j}\in\Delta$ für $1\le j\le n$ und es gelte für $1\le j\le n$:
\begin{align*}
\lim_{z\to\zeta_{j}}\left(z-\zeta_{j}\right)f\left(z\right) & =0
\end{align*}
Dann ist
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =0
\end{align*}
für jede geschlossene Kurve $\gamma$ in $\Delta$'.


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

TODO: Abb5

Wähle Kurven $\gamma_{1}$ und $\gamma_{2}$ so, dass
\begin{itemize}
\item die Kurven keinen der $\zeta_{j}$ schneiden.
\item in einer Umgebung von $z$ die Kurve $\gamma_{1}$ parallel zur imaginären
Achse und $\gamma_{2}$ parallel zur reellen Achse ist.
\end{itemize}
Da nach Theorem \ref{asdf}2.10.2
\begin{align*}
\int_{\partial R}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =0
\end{align*}
ist, folgt wieder:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma_{1}}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{\gamma_{2}}f\left(z\right)\dd z=:F\left(z\right)
\end{align*}
Ab jetzt geht der Beweis genau wie der von Theorem \ref{asdf}2.10.3.

\qqed


\section{Der Cauchysche Integralsatz}

Sei $\gamma$ wieder eine geschlossene Kurve.

Wir wollen nun Funktionen integrieren, die Pole haben.

Beginne speziell mit der Funktion
\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{z-a}
\end{align*}
wobei $a\not\in\text{im}\left(\gamma\right)$ ist.

TODO: Abb6


\subsection{Lemma}

Es gilt
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}\frac{1}{z-a}\dd z & =2\pi\ii\cdot n
\end{align*}
für ein $n\in\mathbb{Z}\setminus\left\{ 0\right\} $.

$\log\left(z-a\right)$ ist eine holomorphe Stammfunktion, aber nicht
auf ganz $\mathbb{C}$.

TODO: Abb7


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

Wähle eine Parametrisierung
\begin{align*}
\gamma:\left[\alpha,\beta\right] & \to\mathbb{C}
\end{align*}
und setze $z\left(t\right)=\gamma\left(t\right)$ und
\begin{align*}
h\left(t\right) & :=\int_{\alpha}^{t}\frac{z'\left(t\right)}{z\left(t\right)-a}\dd t
\end{align*}
TODO: Abb8
\begin{align*}
h'\left(t\right) & =\frac{z'\left(t\right)}{z\left(t\right)-a}
\end{align*}
Dann gilt:
\begin{align*}
e^{-h\left(t\right)}\left(z\left(t\right)-a\right)
\end{align*}
ist stetig und stückweise differenzierbar und hat die Ableitung:
\begin{align*}
\left(e^{-h\left(t\right)}\left(z\left(t\right)-a\right)\right)' & =e^{-h\left(t\right)}\left(-h'\left(t\right)\left(z\left(t\right)-a\right)+z'\left(t\right)\right)=0
\end{align*}
Also ist es eine Konstante $K\in\mathbb{C}$.
\begin{align*}
e^{-h\left(t\right)} & =\frac{K}{z\left(t\right)-a}
\end{align*}
Da $h\left(\alpha\right)=0$ ist, folgt:
\begin{align*}
e^{-h\left(t\right)} & =\frac{z\left(\alpha\right)-a}{z\left(t\right)-a}
\end{align*}
Also gilt:
\begin{align*}
e^{-h\left(\beta\right)} & =\frac{z\left(\alpha\right)-a}{z\left(\beta\right)-a}=1
\end{align*}
Denn die Kurve ist geschlossen, also $z\left(a\right)=z\left(b\right)$.

Damit ergibt sich:
\begin{align*}
h\left(\beta\right) & =\int_{\gamma}\frac{1}{z-a}\dd z=2\pi\ii n
\end{align*}
\qqed

%DATE: 13.1.12


\subsection{Definition \textmd{(Index)}}

Sei $\gamma$ eine geschlossene Kurve, die $a\in\mathbb{C}$ nicht
schneidet. Dann heißt
\begin{align*}
n\left(\gamma,a\right) & =\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\oint_{\gamma}\frac{\dd z}{z-a}
\end{align*}
der \emph{Index} von $\gamma$ bezüglich $a$ (oder auch \emph{Windungszahl}).


\subsection{Theorem \textmd{(Cauchyscher Integralsatz)}}

Sei $f:\Delta=B_{R}\left(0\right)\to\mathbb{C}$ holomorph und $\gamma$
eine geschlossene Kurve in $\Delta$.

Dann ist für jedes $a\in\Delta$, das nicht auf $\gamma$ liegt
\begin{align*}
n\left(\gamma,a\right)\cdot f\left(a\right) & =\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\oint_{\gamma}\frac{f\left(z\right)}{z-a}\dd z
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Beweis}

Setze
\begin{align*}
F\left(z\right) & =\frac{f\left(z\right)-f\left(a\right)}{z-a}
\end{align*}
ist auf $\Delta\setminus\left\{ a\right\} $ holomorph.
\begin{align*}
\lim_{z\to a}\left(z-a\right)F\left(z\right) & =\lim_{z\to a}\left(f\left(z\right)-f\left(a\right)\right)\stackrel{f\text{ stetig}}{=}0
\end{align*}
Also können wir Theorem \ref{sub:Thm-OintHolomHebPol} anwenden und
erhalten:
\begin{align*}
0 & =\oint_{\gamma}F\left(z\right)\dd z=\oint_{\gamma}\frac{f\left(z\right)}{z-a}\dd z-f\left(a\right)\cdot\oint_{\gamma}\frac{1}{z-a}\dd z=\\
 & =\oint_{\gamma}\frac{f\left(z\right)}{z-a}\dd z-f\left(a\right)\cdot2\pi\ii\cdot n\left(\gamma,a\right)
\end{align*}
Also folgt:
\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\oint_{\gamma}\frac{f\left(z\right)}{z-a}\dd z & =f\left(a\right)\cdot n\left(\gamma,a\right)
\end{align*}
\qqed


\subsection{Korollar}

Sind $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ holomorph, $a\in\Delta$ und $\gamma=\partial B_{\varepsilon}\left(a\right)\subseteq\Delta$,
so gilt:
\begin{align*}
f\left(a\right) & =\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\ointctrclockwise_{\gamma}\frac{f\left(z\right)}{z-a}\dd z
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Beweis}

Der Index ist eins, weil gilt:
\begin{align*}
\oint_{\partial B_{\varepsilon}\left(0\right)}\frac{1}{z}\dd z & =2\pi\ii
\end{align*}
\qqed


\subsubsection*{Bemerkung und Definition \textmd{(Zusammenhangskomponenten)}}

Also ist $f\left(a\right)$ eindeutig bestimmt durch $f|_{\partial B_{\varepsilon}\left(a\right)}$,
das heißt $f$ kann nicht in einer kleinen Umgebung um $a$ abgeändert
werden.
\begin{align*}
\nabla^{2}\text{Re}\left(f\right) & =0=\nabla^{2}\text{Im}\left(f\right)\\
\frac{\partial f}{\partial x} & =-\ii\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}
\end{align*}
Diese harmonische Differentialgleichung ist im Innern eindeutig durch
die Randwerte bestimmt.

Eigenschaften des Index:
\begin{align*}
n\left(\gamma,a\right) & =\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\ointctrclockwise_{\gamma}\frac{\dd z}{z-a}=\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\int_{a}^{b}\frac{\gamma'\left(\tau\right)}{\gamma\left(\tau\right)}\dd\tau
\end{align*}
Gehe Kurven rückwärts oder setze geschlossene Kurven aneinander:
\begin{align*}
n\left(-\gamma,a\right) & =-n\left(\gamma,a\right)\\
n\left(\gamma_{1}+\gamma_{2},a\right) & =n\left(\gamma_{1},a\right)+n\left(\gamma_{2},a\right)
\end{align*}


TODO: Abb1

Das Bild (engl. \quotedblbase{}\foreignlanguage{english}{image}\textquotedblleft{})
$\text{im}\left(\gamma\right)$ (beziehungsweise engl. \quotedblbase{}\foreignlanguage{english}{the
range}\textquotedblleft{} $\text{Rg}\left(\gamma\right)$$ $)
\begin{align*}
\text{im}\left(\gamma\right) & :=\gamma\left(\left[a,b\right]\right)
\end{align*}
ist eine kompakte, also abgeschlossene und beschränkte Teilmenge von
$\mathbb{C}$ und
\begin{align*}
\mathbb{C}\setminus\text{im}\left(\gamma\right)
\end{align*}
ist eine offene Teilmenge von $\mathbb{C}$.
\begin{align*}
n\left(\gamma\right):\mathbb{C}\setminus\text{im}\left(\gamma\right) & \to\mathbb{Z}:a\mapsto n\left(\gamma,a\right)
\end{align*}
Für offene Teilmengen von $\mathbb{C}$ ist zusammenhängend $\Leftrightarrow$
wegzusammenhängend (auch genannt bogenzusammenhängend).
\begin{align*}
\mathbb{C}\setminus\text{Rg}\left(\gamma\right) & =\bcupd_{\lambda\in\Lambda}\Omega_{\lambda}
\end{align*}
$\Omega_{\lambda}$ heißen \emph{die Zusammenhangskomponenten} und
für alle $\lambda$ aus der Indexmenge $\Lambda$ ist $\Omega_{\lambda}$
zusammenhängend.

Es könnte auch unendlich viele Zusammenhangskomponenten geben.

TODO: Abb2

Da $\text{im}\left(\gamma\right)$ beschränkt ist, gibt es einen Radius
$R$, so dass gilt:
\begin{align*}
\text{im}\left(\gamma\right) & \subseteq\Delta=B_{R}\left(0\right)
\end{align*}
TODO: Abb3


\subsection{Satz}

\begin{iiilist}

\iii Falls $\left|a\right|>R$ ist, so gilt $n\left(\gamma,a\right)=0$.

\iii Auf jeder Zusammenhangskomponente ist $n\left(\gamma,.\right):\Omega_{\lambda}\to\mathbb{N},x\mapsto n\left(\gamma,x\right)$
konstant.

\end{iiilist}


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\begin{iiilist}

\iii ${\displaystyle \frac{1}{z-a}}$ ist auf ganz $\Delta$ holomorph.
Nach Theorem \ref{asdf}2.10.3 folgt:
\begin{align*}
\oint\frac{\dd z}{z-a} & =0
\end{align*}
\qqed[\roman{ale2})]

\iii Seien $a_{1},a_{2}\in\Omega_{\lambda}$. Mann kann dann $a_{1}$
und $a_{2}$ durch einen Polygonzug miteinander verbinden.

Es genügt zu zeigen, dass gilt:
\begin{align*}
n\left(\gamma,a\right) & =n\left(\gamma,b\right)
\end{align*}
Dabei ist die Verbindungslinie $v\left(a,b\right):=\left\{ \tau a+\left(1-\tau\right)b|0\le\tau\le1\right\} $
von $a$ nach $b$ eine Teilmenge von $\Omega_{\lambda}$.

Es folgt
\begin{align*}
v\left(a,b\right)\cap\text{im}\left(\gamma\right) & =\emptyset
\end{align*}
und damit ist ${\displaystyle \frac{z-a}{z-b}}$ auf $\gamma$ nicht
Element von $\mathbb{R}_{\le0}$, denn wäre ${\displaystyle \frac{z-a}{z-b}}=-c$
für ein $c\in\mathbb{R}_{\ge0}$, so wäre $z-a=-c\left(z-b\right)$,
also würde $z\in v\left(a,b\right)$ folgen.

TODO: Abb4?

Folglich ist ${\displaystyle \log\left(\frac{z-a}{z-b}\right)}$ längs
$\gamma$ wohldefiniert, wobei bei $\log\left(z\right)$ wieder die
komplexe Ebene auf der negativen reellen Achse \quotedblbase{}geschlitzt\textquotedblleft{}
ist.
\begin{align*}
\left(\log\left(\frac{z-a}{z-b}\right)\right)' & =\frac{1}{\frac{z-a}{z-b}}\left(\frac{1}{z-b}-\frac{z-a}{\left(z-b\right)^{2}}\right)=\frac{1}{z-a}-\frac{1}{z-b}
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\oint_{\gamma}\left(\frac{1}{z-a}-\frac{1}{z-b}\right)\dd z & =\log\left(\frac{z-a}{z-b}\right)\bigg|_{z_{0}}^{z_{0}}=n\left(\gamma,a\right)=n\left(\gamma,b\right)
\end{align*}


\end{iiilist}

\qqed


\subsection{Lemma}

Seien $z_{1},z_{2}$ zwei Punkte auf einer geschlossenen Kurve $\gamma$,
die nicht durch den Ursprung geht.

Es sei $\text{Im}\left(z_{1}\right)<0$ und $\text{Im}\left(z_{2}\right)>0$.

Bezeichne die Teilkurven von $z_{1}$ nach $z_{2}$ mit $\gamma_{1}$
und die von $z_{2}$ nach $z_{1}$ mit $\gamma_{2}$.

Falls $\gamma_{1}$ die negative reelle Achse nicht schneidet und
$\gamma_{2}$ die positive reelle Achse nicht schneidet, dann ist
$n\left(\gamma,0\right)=1$.

TODO: Abb5


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

Sei $L_{1}$ der Strahl durch 0 und $z_{1}$ und $L_{2}$ der Strahl
durch 0 und $z_{2}$.

Sei $C$ ein Kreis um Ursprung, der $\gamma$ nicht schneidet.

Wähle $\sigma_{1}$ und $\sigma_{2}$ wie in der Zeichnung.

TODO: Wie genau werden die $\sigma$ gewählt?
\begin{align*}
\oint_{\sigma_{1}}\frac{\dd z}{z-a} & =0=\oint_{\sigma_{2}}\frac{\dd z}{z-a}
\end{align*}
Denn 0 ist in derselben Zusammenhangskomponente wie ein beliebiges
$a\in\mathbb{C}$ mit $\left|a\right|>R$.
\begin{align*}
n\left(\sigma_{1},a\right) & =0
\end{align*}
Nach Satz \ref{asdf}2.11.5 i).

Die Kurve $\mathcal{C}$ (siehe Zeichnung) schneidet nach Konstruktion
$\sigma_{1}$ nicht.

Also liegen $a,0$ in der gleichen Zusammenhangskomponente von $\mathbb{C}\setminus\text{im}\left(\sigma_{1}\right)$,
weswegen $n\left(\sigma_{1},0\right)=0$.

Damit folgt:
\begin{align*}
0 & =n\left(\sigma_{1},0\right)+n\left(\sigma_{2},0\right)=\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\oint_{\sigma_{1}}\frac{\dd z}{z}+\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\oint_{\sigma_{2}}\frac{\dd z}{z}=\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\oint_{\gamma}\frac{\dd z}{z}-\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\underbrace{\oint_{C}\frac{\dd z}{z}}_{=2\pi\ii}=n\left(\gamma,0\right)-1
\end{align*}
Damit folgt:
\begin{align*}
n\left(\gamma,0\right) & =1
\end{align*}
\qqed


\section{Einfache Folgerungen aus dem Cauchyschen Integralsatz}

TODO: Abb7

Seien $\Omega\subseteq\mathbb{C}$ offen, $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$
holomorph und $a\in\Omega$.

Wähle $\varepsilon\in\mathbb{R}_{>0}$ so, dass $B_{2\varepsilon}\left(a\right)\subseteq\Omega$
gilt und definiere $C:=\partial B_{2\varepsilon}\left(a\right)$.

Für alle $z\in B_{\varepsilon}\left(a\right)$ gilt dann:
\begin{align*}
f\left(z\right) & =\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\oint_{C}\frac{f\left(\zeta\right)}{\zeta-z}\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
Nehme an, dass man unter dem Integral nach $z$ ableiten darf, was
wir später rechtfertigen werden.
\begin{align*}
f'\left(z\right) & =\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\oint\frac{f\left(\zeta\right)}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{2}}\dd\zeta\\
\vdots\quad\\
f^{\left(n\right)}\left(z\right) & =\frac{n!}{2\pi\ii}\oint\frac{f\left(\zeta\right)}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n+1}}\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
Also sollte $f$ beliebig oft komplex differenzierbar sein.
\begin{align*}
\left|f^{\left(n\right)}\left(z\right)\right| & \le\sup_{C}\frac{\left|f\left(\zeta\right)\right|}{\left|\zeta-z\right|^{n+1}}\cdot\underbrace{2\pi\cdot2\varepsilon}_{\text{Länge von }C}\le\\
 & \le2\varepsilon\cdot n!\cdot\frac{1}{\varepsilon^{n+1}}\cdot\sup_{C}\left|f\right|\le\\
 & \le\underbrace{2\sup_{C}\left|f\right|}_{=:\mathcal{C}}\cdot\frac{n!}{\varepsilon^{n}}
\end{align*}
TODO: Stimmt diese Definition von $\mathcal{C}$???

\quotedblbase{}Man hat unter Kontrolle wie rasch die Ableitungen in
$n$ ansteigen.\textquotedblleft{}

Betrachte die Taylorreihe:
\begin{align*}
f\left(z\right) & =\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{f^{\left(n\right)}\left(z_{0}\right)}{n!}\left(z-z_{0}\right)^{n}
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\left|\frac{f^{\left(n\right)}\left(z_{0}\right)}{n!}\left(z-z_{0}\right)\right|^{n} & \le\mathcal{C}\cdot\left(\frac{\left|z-z_{0}\right|}{\varepsilon}\right)^{n}
\end{align*}
Falls $\left|z-z_{0}\right|<\varepsilon$ ist die geometrische Reihe
eine konvergente Majorante.

%DATE: Di 17.1.12


\subsection{Lemma}

TODO: Abb1

Sei $\Omega\subseteq\mathbb{C}$ offen. 

Sei $\varphi\left(\zeta\right)$ stetig auf der geschlossene Kontur
$\gamma:=\partial\Delta$, mit $\Delta:=B_{2\varepsilon}\left(a\right)\subseteq\Omega$
das heißt $\gamma:\left[\alpha,\beta\right]\to\mathbb{C},\left(f\circ\gamma\right):\left[\alpha,\beta\right]\to\mathbb{C}$
soll stetig sein.

TODO: \quotedblbase{}das Kontur\textquotedblleft{} ??

Dann sind die Funktionen
\begin{align*}
F_{n}\left(z\right) & =\oint\frac{\varphi\left(\zeta\right)}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n}}\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
mit $n\in\mathbb{N}$ auf $B_{\varepsilon}\left(a\right)$ holomorph
und $F_{n}'\left(z\right)=n\cdot F_{n+1}\left(z\right)$.


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\begin{abclist}

\abc Zeige, dass $F_{1}\left(z\right)$ stetig ist:

Sei $z_{0}\in B_{\varepsilon}\left(a\right)$. Wähle $\delta>0$ so,
dass $B_{2\delta}\left(z_{0}\right)\subseteq B_{\varepsilon}\left(a\right)$.
Sei $z\in B_{\delta}\left(z_{0}\right)$.
\begin{align*}
F_{1}\left(z\right)-F_{1}\left(z_{0}\right) & =\oint_{\gamma}\varphi\left(\zeta\right)\underbrace{\left(\frac{1}{\zeta-z}-\frac{1}{\zeta-z_{0}}\right)}_{=\frac{z-z_{0}}{\left(\zeta-z\right)\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)}}\dd\zeta=\left(z-z_{0}\right)\oint_{\gamma}\frac{\varphi\left(\zeta\right)}{\left(\zeta-z\right)\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)}\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
Wir wissen, dass $\left|\zeta-z\right|\ge\varepsilon$ und $\left|\zeta-z_{0}\right|\ge\varepsilon$
ist.

Damit folgt:
\begin{align*}
\left|F\left(z\right)-F\left(z_{0}\right)\right| & \le\left|z-z_{0}\right|\cdot\frac{1}{\varepsilon^{2}}\cdot\oint_{\gamma}\left|\varphi\left(\zeta\right)\right|\underbrace{\left|\dd\zeta\right|}_{=\left|\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right|\dd\tau}\le\\
 & \le\left|z-z_{0}\right|\cdot\frac{1}{\varepsilon^{2}}\cdot\sup_{\gamma}\left|\varphi\right|\cdot2\pi\cdot2\varepsilon
\end{align*}
Also ist $F$ lipschitz-stetig in $z_{0}$.

\abc $F_{1}$ ist komplex differenzierbar in $z=z_{0}$ und $F_{1}'\left(z_{0}\right)=F_{2}\left(z_{0}\right)$.

Betrachte die Abschätzung aus a) für $\varphi\left(\zeta\right)$
ersetzt durch ${\displaystyle \frac{\varphi\left(\zeta\right)}{\zeta-z_{0}}}$,
also ist
\begin{align*}
G_{1}\left(z\right) & =\oint\frac{\varphi\left(\zeta\right)}{\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)\left(\zeta-z\right)}\dd\zeta=\frac{F_{1}\left(z\right)-F_{1}\left(z_{0}\right)}{z-z_{0}}
\end{align*}
stetig in $z_{0}$. Also existiert der Limes:
\begin{align*}
\lim_{z\to z_{0}}\frac{F_{1}\left(z\right)-F_{1}\left(z_{0}\right)}{z-z_{0}}
\end{align*}
Nochmals erklärt:
\begin{align*}
F_{1}\left(z\right) & =\oint_{\gamma}\frac{\varphi\left(\zeta\right)}{\zeta-z}\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
F_{1}\left(z\right)-F_{1}\left(z_{0}\right) & =\left(z-z_{0}\right)\oint_{\gamma}\frac{\varphi\left(\zeta\right)}{\left(\zeta-z\right)\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)}\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
Daher gilt:
\begin{align*}
\frac{F_{1}\left(z\right)-F_{1}\left(z_{0}\right)}{z-z_{0}} & =\oint_{\gamma}\frac{\psi\left(\zeta\right)}{\zeta-z}\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
Dabei ist:
\begin{align*}
\psi\left(\zeta\right) & :=\frac{\varphi\left(\zeta\right)}{\zeta-z_{0}}
\end{align*}
Da $\psi$ stetig ist, ist das Konturintegral stetig und daher konvergiert
der Differenzenquotient.

\abc Der allgemeine Fall folgt durch Induktion:
\begin{align*}
F_{n}\left(z\right)-F_{n}\left(z_{0}\right) & =\oint_{\gamma}\varphi\left(\zeta\right)\left(\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n}}\cdot1-\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)^{n}}\right)\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
Für die Stetigkeit verwende folgendes Ergebnis:

TODO: Differenzierbarkeit?
\begin{description}
\item [{Behauptung}] \hspace*{1mm}\\
Für $p,q\in\mathbb{N}$ gilt:
\begin{align*}
\lim_{z\to z_{0}}\oint_{\gamma}\varphi\left(\zeta\right)\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)^{p}\left(\zeta-z\right)^{q}}\dd\zeta & =\oint\varphi\left(\zeta\right)\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{p+q}}\dd\zeta
\end{align*}

\item [{Beweis}] \hspace*{1mm}\\
\begin{align*}
\oint\varphi\left(\zeta\right)\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)^{p}\left(\zeta-z\right)^{q}}\dd\zeta & =\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\frac{\varphi\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)}{\underbrace{\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)-z_{0}\right)^{p}\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)-z\right)^{q}}_{\to}}\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau\stackrel{z\to z_{0}}{\longrightarrow}\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\frac{\varphi\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)}{\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)-z_{0}\right)^{p+q}}\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}
Benutze folgende Identität:
\begin{align*}
1 & =\frac{\zeta-z_{0}}{\zeta-z_{0}}=\frac{\zeta-z}{\zeta-z_{0}}+\frac{z-z_{0}}{\zeta-z_{0}}
\end{align*}
Damit ergibt sich:
\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n}} & =\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n}}\cdot\frac{\zeta-z_{0}}{\zeta-z_{0}}=\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n}}\cdot\left(\frac{\zeta-z}{\zeta-z_{0}}+\frac{z-z_{0}}{\zeta-z_{0}}\right)=\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n-1}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)}+\frac{z-z_{0}}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)}=\\
 & =\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n-1}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)}\frac{\zeta-z_{0}}{\zeta-z_{0}}+\frac{z-z_{0}}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)}=\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n-1}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)}\cdot\left(\frac{\zeta-z}{\zeta-z_{0}}+\frac{z-z_{0}}{\zeta-z_{0}}\right)+\frac{z-z_{0}}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)}=\\
 & =\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n-2}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)^{2}}+\frac{z-z_{0}}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n-1}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)^{2}}+\frac{z-z_{0}}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)}=\\
 & \quad\vdots\\
 & =\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)^{n}}+\underbrace{\frac{z-z_{0}}{\left(\zeta-z\right)\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)^{n}}+\frac{z-z_{0}}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{2}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)^{n-1}}+\ldots+\frac{z-z_{0}}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)}}_{n\text{ Terme}}
\end{align*}
Also gilt:
\begin{align*}
\frac{F_{n}\left(z\right)-F_{n}\left(z_{0}\right)}{z-z_{0}} & =\frac{1}{z-z_{0}}\oint_{\gamma}\varphi\left(\zeta\right)\left(\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n}}-\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)^{n}}\right)\dd\zeta=\\
 & =\oint_{\gamma}\varphi\left(\zeta\right)\left(\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)^{n}}+\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{2}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)^{n-1}}+\ldots+\frac{1}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n}\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)}\right)\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
Damit folgt:
\begin{align*}
F_{n}'\left(z_{0}\right)=\lim_{z\to z_{0}}\frac{F_{n}\left(z\right)-F_{n}\left(z_{0}\right)}{z-z_{0}} & =\int_{\gamma}\varphi\left(\zeta\right)\frac{n}{\left(\zeta-z_{0}\right)^{n+1}}=n\cdot F_{n+1}\left(z_{0}\right)
\end{align*}

\end{description}
\qqed[Behauptung]

\end{abclist}


\subsection{Theorem}

Jede holomorphe Funktion $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ ist in $\Omega$
unendlich oft komplex differenzierbar und es gilt:
\begin{align*}
f^{\left(n\right)}\left(z\right) & =\frac{n!}{2\pi\ii}\oint_{\gamma}\frac{f\left(\zeta\right)}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{n+1}}\dd z
\end{align*}
Dabei ist $\gamma$ eine Kurve in $\Omega$, die $z$ mit Index $1$
umläuft.


\subsection{Theorem \textmd{(Moera)}}

TODO: Name???

Falls $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ stetig und für jede geschlossene Kurve
in $\Omega$ schon $\oint_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z=0$ gilt, ist
$f$ holomorph.


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

Nach Theorem \ref{asdf}2.9.1 gibt es eine holomorphe Stammfunktion
$F:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ und $F'\left(z\right)=f\left(z\right)$.

Da $F$ nach Theorem \ref{asdf}2.12.2 zweimal differenzierbar ist,
folgt, dass $f$ differenzierbar und damit holomorph ist.

\qqed


\subsection{Theorem \textmd{(Liouville)}}

Eine beschränkte, auf ganz $\mathbb{C}$ holomorphe Funktion ist konstant.


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

TODO: Abb2

Für $R>2\left|z\right|$ gilt:

\begin{align*}
f\left(z\right) & =\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\oint_{\partial B_{R}\left(0\right)}\frac{f\left(\zeta\right)}{\zeta-z}\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\left|\zeta-z\right| & >\frac{R}{2}
\end{align*}
Nach Theorem \ref{asdf}2.12.2 gilt:
\begin{align*}
f'\left(z\right) & =\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\oint_{\partial B_{R}\left(0\right)}\frac{f\left(\zeta\right)}{\left(\zeta-z\right)^{2}}\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\left|f'\left(z\right)\right| & \le\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\left|f'\left(z\right)\right| & \le\frac{1}{2\pi}\left(\frac{2}{R}\right)^{2}\cdot\sup_{\partial B_{R}\left(0\right)}\left|f\right|\cdot2\pi R\le\frac{4}{R}\cdot\underbrace{\sup_{\mathbb{C}}\left|f\right|}_{\le C}\stackrel{R\to\infty}{\longrightarrow}0
\end{align*}
Da $R$ beliebig groß gewählt werden kann, folgt $f'\left(z\right)=0$.

Wir sehen also, dass gilt:

TODO: Abb3
\begin{align*}
f'\left(z\right) & =0
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
f\left(z_{1}\right)-f\left(z_{0}\right) & =\int_{\gamma}f'\left(z\right)\dd z=0
\end{align*}
Damit folgt:
\begin{align*}
f\left(z_{1}\right) & =f\left(z_{0}\right)
\end{align*}
Also ist $f$ konstant.

\qqed


\subsection{Eleganter Beweis des Fundamentalsatzes der Algebra}

Nehme an, $P\left(z\right)$ sei ein Polynom vom Grade $\ge1$ ohne
Nullstellen.

Damit folgt:
\begin{align*}
f\left(z\right) & :=\frac{1}{P\left(z\right)}
\end{align*}
ist holomorph auf ganz $\mathbb{C}$, da $f'\left(z\right)=-\frac{P'\left(z\right)}{P\left(z\right)^{2}}$
ist.
\begin{align*}
P\left(z\right) & =a_{n}z^{n}\left(1+\frac{a_{n-1}}{a_{n}}\frac{1}{z}+\ldots\right)
\end{align*}
Also ist $\lim_{z\to\infty}\left|P\left(z\right)\right|=\infty$ und
somit:
\begin{align*}
\lim_{z\to\infty}f\left(z\right) & =0
\end{align*}
Daher ist $f$ auf ganz $\mathbb{C}$ holomorph und beschränkt und
damit nach dem Satz von Liouville \ref{asdf}?? konstant.

Also ist $P\left(z\right)$ konstant, was ein Widerspruch ist.

\qqed

Bedingung für \quotedblbase{}Ausnahmepunkte\textquotedblleft{}:
\begin{align*}
\lim_{z\to\zeta}\left(z-\zeta\right)f\left(z\right) & =0
\end{align*}



\section{Hebbare Singularitäten, Taylorreihen}


\subsection{Satz}

Sei $\Omega\subseteq\mathbb{C}$ offen.

Sei $\Omega'=\Omega\setminus\left\{ a\right\} $, $f:\Omega'\to\mathbb{C}$
holomorph.

Es gelte:
\begin{align*}
\sr{\lim_{z\to a}}{}{z\not=a}\left(z-a\right)f\left(z\right) & =0
\end{align*}


Dann gibt es eine holomorphe Funktion
\begin{align*}
\tilde{f}:\Omega & \to\mathbb{C}
\end{align*}
mit $\tilde{f}|_{\Omega'}=f$.

Die Umkehrung gilt auch.

Die Funktion $\tilde{f}$ ist eindeutig bestimmt.

$\tilde{f}$ heißt \emph{holomorphe Fortsetzung} von $f$.

$a$ heißt \emph{hebbare Singularität}.


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\quotedblbase{}$\Leftarrow$\textquotedblleft{}: Sei $\tilde{f}$
holomorphe Fortsetzung. Dann gilt
\begin{align*}
\sr{\lim_{z\to a}}{}{z\not=a}\left(z-a\right)f\left(z\right) & =\lim_{z\to a}\left(z-a\right)\tilde{f}\left(z\right)=0
\end{align*}
weil $\tilde{f}$ stetig ist.

Die Eindeutigkeit ist wegen der Stetigkeit klar:
\begin{align*}
\tilde{f}\left(a\right) & =\lim_{z\to a}\tilde{f}\left(z\right)=\sr{\lim_{z\to a}}{}{z\not=a}f\left(z\right)
\end{align*}
\quotedblbase{}$\Rightarrow$\textquotedblleft{}: Sei $C=\partial B_{\varepsilon}\left(a\right)\subseteq\Omega$.

Betrachte für $z\in B_{\varepsilon}\left(a\right)\setminus\left\{ a\right\} $
die Funktion:
\begin{align*}
G\left(\xi\right) & =\frac{f\left(\xi\right)-f\left(z\right)}{\xi-z}
\end{align*}
Diese Funktion ist holomorph in $\Omega\setminus\left\{ a,z\right\} $
und erfüllt die Bedingungen von Theorem \ref{asdf}2.10.4, also für
$\xi\in\left\{ a,z\right\} $:
\begin{align*}
\sr{\lim_{z\to\xi}}{}{z\not=\xi}\left(z-\xi\right)G\left(\xi\right) & =0
\end{align*}
Also gilt
\begin{align*}
\oint_{\gamma}G\left(z\right)\dd z & =0
\end{align*}
und folglich:
\begin{align*}
f\left(z\right) & =\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\oint_{C}\frac{f\left(\zeta\right)}{\zeta-z}\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
Dies ist genau wie im Beweis des Cauchyschen-Integralsatzes \ref{asdf}??.

Da das Integral auch für $z=a$ wohldefiniert ist, können wir setzen
\begin{align*}
\tilde{f}\left(z\right) & :=\frac{1}{2\pi\ii}\oint_{C}\frac{f\left(\zeta\right)}{\zeta-z}\dd\zeta
\end{align*}
auf $B_{\varepsilon}\left(a\right)$, einschließlich $z=a$.

$\tilde{f}:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ und definiert durch
\begin{align*}
\tilde{f}\left(z\right) & =\begin{cases}
\frac{1}{2\pi\ii} & \text{falls }z\in B_{\varepsilon}\left(a\right)\\
f\left(z\right) & \text{sonst}
\end{cases}
\end{align*}
\qqed

but changing it is not allowed.

\section*{\noun{0. Preamble}}

\noindent The purpose of this License is to make a manual, textbook,
or other functional and useful document \textquotedblleft{}free\textquotedblright{}
in the sense of freedom: to assure everyone the effective freedom
to copy and redistribute it, with or without modifying it, either
commercially or noncommercially. Secondarily, this License preserves
for the author and publisher a way to get credit for their work, while
not being considered responsible for modifications made by others.

\noindent This License is a kind of \textquotedblleft{}copyleft\textquotedblright{},
which means that derivative works of the document must themselves
be free in the same sense. It complements the GNU General Public License,
which is a copyleft license designed for free software.

\noindent We have designed this License in order to use it for manuals
for free software, because free software needs free documentation:
a free program should come with manuals providing the same freedoms
that the software does. But this License is not limited to software
manuals; it can be used for any textual work, regardless of subject
matter or whether it is published as a printed book. We recommend
this License principally for works whose purpose is instruction or
reference.


\section*{\noun{1. Applicability and definitions}}

This License applies to any manual or other work, in any medium, that
contains a notice placed by the copyright holder saying it can be
distributed under the terms of this License. Such a notice grants
a world-wide, royalty-free license, unlimited in duration, to use
that work under the conditions stated herein. The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Document}\textquotedblright{},
below, refers to any such manual or work. Any member of the public
is a licensee, and is addressed as \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{you}\textquotedblright{}.
You accept the license if you copy, modify or distribute the work
in a way requiring permission under copyright law.

A \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Modified Version}\textquotedblright{}
of the Document means any work containing the Document or a portion
of it, either copied verbatim, or with modifications and/or translated
into another language.

A \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Secondary Section}\textquotedblright{}
is a named appendix or a front-matter section of the Document that
deals exclusively with the relationship of the publishers or authors
of the Document to the Document's overall subject (or to related matters)
and contains nothing that could fall directly within that overall
subject. (Thus, if the Document is in part a textbook of mathematics,
a Secondary Section may not explain any mathematics.) The relationship
could be a matter of historical connection with the subject or with
related matters, or of legal, commercial, philosophical, ethical or
political position regarding them.

The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Invariant Sections}\textquotedblright{}
are certain Secondary Sections whose titles are designated, as being
those of Invariant Sections, in the notice that says that the Document
is released under this License. If a section does not fit the above
definition of Secondary then it is not allowed to be designated as
Invariant. The Document may contain zero Invariant Sections. If the
Document does not identify any Invariant Sections then there are none.

The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Cover Texts}\textquotedblright{} are
certain short passages of text that are listed, as Front-Cover Texts
or Back-Cover Texts, in the notice that says that the Document is
released under this License. A Front-Cover Text may be at most 5 words,
and a Back-Cover Text may be at most 25 words.

A \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Transparent}\textquotedblright{} copy
of the Document means a machine-readable copy, represented in a format
whose specification is available to the general public, that is suitable
for revising the document straightforwardly with generic text editors
or (for images composed of pixels) generic paint programs or (for
drawings) some widely available drawing editor, and that is suitable
for input to text formatters or for automatic translation to a variety
of formats suitable for input to text formatters. A copy made in an
otherwise Transparent file format whose markup, or absence of markup,
has been arranged to thwart or discourage subsequent modification
by readers is not Transparent. An image format is not Transparent
if used for any substantial amount of text. A copy that is not \textquotedblleft{}Transparent\textquotedblright{}
is called \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Opaque}\textquotedblright{}.

Examples of suitable formats for Transparent copies include plain
ASCII without markup, Texinfo input format, \LaTeX{} input format,
SGML or XML using a publicly available DTD, and standard-conforming
simple HTML, PostScript or PDF designed for human modification. Examples
of transparent image formats include PNG, XCF and JPG. Opaque formats
include proprietary formats that can be read and edited only by proprietary
word processors, SGML or XML for which the DTD and/or processing tools
are not generally available, and the machine-generated HTML, PostScript
or PDF produced by some word processors for output purposes only.

The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Title Page}\textquotedblright{} means,
for a printed book, the title page itself, plus such following pages
as are needed to hold, legibly, the material this License requires
to appear in the title page. For works in formats which do not have
any title page as such, \textquotedblleft{}Title Page\textquotedblright{}
means the text near the most prominent appearance of the work's title,
preceding the beginning of the body of the text.

The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{publisher}\textquotedblright{} means
any person or entity that distributes copies of the Document to the
public.

A section \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Entitled XYZ}\textquotedblright{}
means a named subunit of the Document whose title either is precisely
XYZ or contains XYZ in parentheses following text that translates
XYZ in another language. (Here XYZ stands for a specific section name
mentioned below, such as \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Acknowledgements}\textquotedblright{},
\textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Dedications}\textquotedblright{}, \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Endorsements}\textquotedblright{},
or \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{History}\textquotedblright{}.) To \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Preserve
the Title}\textquotedblright{} of such a section when you modify the
Document means that it remains a section \textquotedblleft{}Entitled
XYZ\textquotedblright{} according to this definition.

The Document may include Warranty Disclaimers next to the notice which
states that this License applies to the Document. These Warranty Disclaimers
are considered to be included by reference in this License, but only
as regards disclaiming warranties: any other implication that these
Warranty Disclaimers may have is void and has no effect on the meaning
of this License.


\section*{\noun{2. Verbatim copying}}

You may copy and distribute the Document in any medium, either commercially
or noncommercially, provided that this License, the copyright notices,
and the license notice saying this License applies to the Document
are reproduced in all copies, and that you add no other conditions
whatsoever to those of this License. You may not use technical measures
to obstruct or control the reading or further copying of the copies
you make or distribute. However, you may accept compensation in exchange
for copies. If you distribute a large enough number of copies you
must also follow the conditions in section 3.

You may also lend copies, under the same conditions stated above,
and you may publicly display copies.


\section*{\noun{3. Copying in quantity}}

If you publish printed copies (or copies in media that commonly have
printed covers) of the Document, numbering more than 100, and the
Document's license notice requires Cover Texts, you must enclose the
copies in covers that carry, clearly and legibly, all these Cover
Texts: Front-Cover Texts on the front cover, and Back-Cover Texts
on the back cover. Both covers must also clearly and legibly identify
you as the publisher of these copies. The front cover must present
the full title with all words of the title equally prominent and visible.
You may add other material on the covers in addition. Copying with
changes limited to the covers, as long as they preserve the title
of the Document and satisfy these conditions, can be treated as verbatim
copying in other respects.

If the required texts for either cover are too voluminous to fit legibly,
you should put the first ones listed (as many as fit reasonably) on
the actual cover, and continue the rest onto adjacent pages.

If you publish or distribute Opaque copies of the Document numbering
more than 100, you must either include a machine-readable Transparent
copy along with each Opaque copy, or state in or with each Opaque
copy a computer-network location from which the general network-using
public has access to download using public-standard network protocols
a complete Transparent copy of the Document, free of added material.
If you use the latter option, you must take reasonably prudent steps,
when you begin distribution of Opaque copies in quantity, to ensure
that this Transparent copy will remain thus accessible at the stated
location until at least one year after the last time you distribute
an Opaque copy (directly or through your agents or retailers) of that
edition to the public.

It is requested, but not required, that you contact the authors of
the Document well before redistributing any large number of copies,
to give them a chance to provide you with an updated version of the
Document.


\section*{\noun{4. Modifications}}

You may copy and distribute a Modified Version of the Document under
the conditions of sections 2 and 3 above, provided that you release
the Modified Version under precisely this License, with the Modified
Version filling the role of the Document, thus licensing distribution
and modification of the Modified Version to whoever possesses a copy
of it. In addition, you must do these things in the Modified Version:
\begin{description}
\item [{A.\hspace*{3.2mm}}] Use in the Title Page (and on the covers,
if any) a title distinct from that of the Document, and from those
of previous versions (which should, if there were any, be listed in
the History section of the Document). You may use the same title as
a previous version if the original publisher of that version gives
permission.
\item [{B.\hspace*{3.4mm}}] List on the Title Page, as authors, one or
more persons or entities responsible for authorship of the modifications
in the Modified Version, together with at least five of the principal
authors of the Document (all of its principal authors, if it has fewer
than five), unless they release you from this requirement.
\item [{C.\hspace*{3.4mm}}] State on the Title page the name of the publisher
of the Modified Version, as the publisher.
\item [{D.\hspace*{3.4mm}}] Preserve all the copyright notices of the
Document.
\item [{E.\hspace*{3.4mm}}] Add an appropriate copyright notice for your
modifications adjacent to the other copyright notices.
\item [{F.\hspace*{3.8mm}}] Include, immediately after the copyright notices,
a license notice giving the public permission to use the Modified
Version under the terms of this License, in the form shown in the
Addendum below.
\item [{G.\hspace*{3.1mm}}] Preserve in that license notice the full lists
of Invariant Sections and required Cover Texts given in the Document's
license notice.
\item [{H.\hspace*{3.2mm}}] Include an unaltered copy of this License.
\item [{I.\hspace*{5.0mm}}] Preserve the section Entitled \textquotedblleft{}History\textquotedblright{},
Preserve its Title, and add to it an item stating at least the title,
year, new authors, and publisher of the Modified Version as given
on the Title Page. If there is no section Entitled \textquotedblleft{}History\textquotedblright{}
in the Document, create one stating the title, year, authors, and
publisher of the Document as given on its Title Page, then add an
item describing the Modified Version as stated in the previous sentence.
\item [{J.\hspace*{4.3mm}}] Preserve the network location, if any, given
in the Document for public access to a Transparent copy of the Document,
and likewise the network locations given in the Document for previous
versions it was based on. These may be placed in the \textquotedblleft{}History\textquotedblright{}
section. You may omit a network location for a work that was published
at least four years before the Document itself, or if the original
publisher of the version it refers to gives permission.
\item [{K.\hspace*{3.3mm}}] For any section Entitled \textquotedblleft{}Acknowledgements\textquotedblright{}
or \textquotedblleft{}Dedications\textquotedblright{}, Preserve the
Title of the section, and preserve in the section all the substance
and tone of each of the contributor acknowledgements and/or dedications
given therein.
\item [{L.\hspace*{4.1mm}}] Preserve all the Invariant Sections of the
Document, unaltered in their text and in their titles. Section numbers
or the equivalent are not considered part of the section titles.
\item [{M.\hspace*{3mm}}] Delete any section Entitled \textquotedblleft{}Endorsements\textquotedblright{}.
Such a section may not be included in the Modified Version.
\item [{N.\hspace*{3.4mm}}] Do not retitle any existing section to be
Entitled \textquotedblleft{}Endorsements\textquotedblright{} or to
conflict in title with any Invariant Section.
\item [{O.\hspace*{3.4mm}}] Preserve any Warranty Disclaimers.
\end{description}
If the Modified Version includes new front-matter sections or appendices
that qualify as Secondary Sections and contain no material copied
from the Document, you may at your option designate some or all of
these sections as invariant. To do this, add their titles to the list
of Invariant Sections in the Modified Version's license notice. These
titles must be distinct from any other section titles.

You may add a section Entitled \textquotedblleft{}Endorsements\textquotedblright{},
provided it contains nothing but endorsements of your Modified Version
by various parties\textemdash{}for example, statements of peer review
or that the text has been approved by an organization as the authoritative
definition of a standard.

You may add a passage of up to five words as a Front-Cover Text, and
a passage of up to 25 words as a Back-Cover Text, to the end of the
list of Cover Texts in the Modified Version. Only one passage of Front-Cover
Text and one of Back-Cover Text may be added by (or through arrangements
made by) any one entity. If the Document already includes a cover
text for the same cover, previously added by you or by arrangement
made by the same entity you are acting on behalf of, you may not add
another; but you may replace the old one, on explicit permission from
the previous publisher that added the old one.

The author(s) and publisher(s) of the Document do not by this License
give permission to use their names for publicity for or to assert
or imply endorsement of any Modified Version.


\section*{\noun{5. Combining documents}}

You may combine the Document with other documents released under this
License, under the terms defined in section 4 above for modified versions,
provided that you include in the combination all of the Invariant
Sections of all of the original documents, unmodified, and list them
all as Invariant Sections of your combined work in its license notice,
and that you preserve all their Warranty Disclaimers.

The combined work need only contain one copy of this License, and
multiple identical Invariant Sections may be replaced with a single
copy. If there are multiple Invariant Sections with the same name
but different contents, make the title of each such section unique
by adding at the end of it, in parentheses, the name of the original
author or publisher of that section if known, or else a unique number.
Make the same adjustment to the section titles in the list of Invariant
Sections in the license notice of the combined work.

In the combination, you must combine any sections Entitled \textquotedblleft{}History\textquotedblright{}
in the various original documents, forming one section Entitled \textquotedblleft{}History\textquotedblright{};
likewise combine any sections Entitled \textquotedblleft{}Acknowledgements\textquotedblright{},
and any sections Entitled \textquotedblleft{}Dedications\textquotedblright{}.
You must delete all sections Entitled \textquotedblleft{}Endorsements\textquotedblright{}.


\section*{\noun{6. Collections of documents}}

You may make a collection consisting of the Document and other documents
released under this License, and replace the individual copies of
this License in the various documents with a single copy that is included
in the collection, provided that you follow the rules of this License
for verbatim copying of each of the documents in all other respects.

You may extract a single document from such a collection, and distribute
it individually under this License, provided you insert a copy of
this License into the extracted document, and follow this License
in all other respects regarding verbatim copying of that document.


\section*{\noun{7. Aggregation with independent works}}

A compilation of the Document or its derivatives with other separate
and independent documents or works, in or on a volume of a storage
or distribution medium, is called an \textquotedblleft{}aggregate\textquotedblright{}
if the copyright resulting from the compilation is not used to limit
the legal rights of the compilation's users beyond what the individual
works permit. When the Document is included in an aggregate, this
License does not apply to the other works in the aggregate which are
not themselves derivative works of the Document.

If the Cover Text requirement of section 3 is applicable to these
copies of the Document, then if the Document is less than one half
of the entire aggregate, the Document's Cover Texts may be placed
on covers that bracket the Document within the aggregate, or the electronic
equivalent of covers if the Document is in electronic form. Otherwise
they must appear on printed covers that bracket the whole aggregate.


\section*{\noun{8. Translation}}

Translation is considered a kind of modification, so you may distribute
translations of the Document under the terms of section 4. Replacing
Invariant Sections with translations requires special permission from
their copyright holders, but you may include translations of some
or all Invariant Sections in addition to the original versions of
these Invariant Sections. You may include a translation of this License,
and all the license notices in the Document, and any Warranty Disclaimers,
provided that you also include the original English version of this
License and the original versions of those notices and disclaimers.
In case of a disagreement between the translation and the original
version of this License or a notice or disclaimer, the original version
will prevail.

If a section in the Document is Entitled \textquotedblleft{}Acknowledgements\textquotedblright{},
\textquotedblleft{}Dedications\textquotedblright{}, or \textquotedblleft{}History\textquotedblright{},
the requirement (section 4) to Preserve its Title (section 1) will
typically require changing the actual title.


\section*{\noun{9. Termination}}

You may not copy, modify, sublicense, or distribute the Document except
as expressly provided under this License. Any attempt otherwise to
copy, modify, sublicense, or distribute it is void, and will automatically
terminate your rights under this License.

However, if you cease all violation of this License, then your license
from a particular copyright holder is reinstated (a) provisionally,
unless and until the copyright holder explicitly and finally terminates
your license, and (b) permanently, if the copyright holder fails to
notify you of the violation by some reasonable means prior to 60 days
after the cessation.

Moreover, your license from a particular copyright holder is reinstated
permanently if the copyright holder notifies you of the violation
by some reasonable means, this is the first time you have received
notice of violation of this License (for any work) from that copyright
holder, and you cure the violation prior to 30 days after your receipt
of the notice.

Termination of your rights under this section does not terminate the
licenses of parties who have received copies or rights from you under
this License. If your rights have been terminated and not permanently
reinstated, receipt of a copy of some or all of the same material
does not give you any rights to use it.


\section*{\noun{10. Future revisions of this license}}

The Free Software Foundation may publish new, revised versions of
the GNU Free Documentation License from time to time. Such new versions
will be similar in spirit to the present version, but may differ in
detail to address new problems or concerns. See \url{https://www.gnu.org/copyleft/}.

Each version of the License is given a distinguishing version number.
If the Document specifies that a particular numbered version of this
License \textquotedbl{}or any later version\textquotedbl{} applies
to it, you have the option of following the terms and conditions either
of that specified version or of any later version that has been published
(not as a draft) by the Free Software Foundation. If the Document
does not specify a version number of this License, you may choose
any version ever published (not as a draft) by the Free Software Foundation.
If the Document specifies that a proxy can decide which future versions
of this License can be used, that proxy's public statement of acceptance
of a version permanently authorizes you to choose that version for
the Document.


\section*{\noun{11. Relicensing}}

\textquotedblleft{}Massive Multiauthor Collaboration Site\textquotedblright{}
(or \textquotedblleft{}MMC Site\textquotedblright{}) means any World
Wide Web server that publishes copyrightable works and also provides
prominent facilities for anybody to edit those works. A public wiki
that anybody can edit is an example of such a server. A \textquotedblleft{}Massive
Multiauthor Collaboration\textquotedblright{} (or \textquotedblleft{}MMC\textquotedblright{})
contained in the site means any set of copyrightable works thus published
on the MMC site.

\textquotedblleft{}CC-BY-SA\textquotedblright{} means the Creative
Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 license published by Creative
Commons Corporation, a not-for-profit corporation with a principal
place of business in San Francisco, California, as well as future
copyleft versions of that license published by that same organization.

\textquotedblleft{}Incorporate\textquotedblright{} means to publish
or republish a Document, in whole or in part, as part of another Document.

An MMC is \textquotedblleft{}eligible for relicensing\textquotedblright{}
if it is licensed under this License, and if all works that were first
published under this License somewhere other than this MMC, and subsequently
incorporated in whole or in part into the MMC, (1) had no cover texts
or invariant sections, and (2) were thus incorporated prior to November
1, 2008.

The operator of an MMC Site may republish an MMC contained in the
site under CC-BY-SA on the same site at any time before August 1,
2009, provided the MMC is eligible for relicensing.


\section*{\noun{Addendum}: How to use this License for your documents}

To use this License in a document you have written, include a copy
of the License in the document and put the following copyright and
license notices just after the title page:
\begin{quote}
Copyright © YEAR YOUR NAME.\\
Permission is granted to copy, distribute and/or modify this document
under the terms of the GNU Free Documentation License, Version 1.3
or any later version published by the Free Software Foundation;

with no Invariant Sections, no Front-Cover Texts, and no Back-Cover
Texts.

A copy of the license is included in the section entitled \textquotedbl{}GNU
Free Documentation License\textquotedbl{}.
\end{quote}
If you have Invariant Sections, Front-Cover Texts and Back-Cover Texts,
replace the \textquotedbl{}with $\ldots$ Texts.\textquotedbl{} line
with this:
\begin{quote}
with the Invariant Sections being LIST THEIR TITLES, with the Front-Cover
Texts being LIST, and with the Back-Cover Texts being LIST.
\end{quote}
If you have Invariant Sections without Cover Texts, or some other
combination of the three, merge those two alternatives to suit the
situation.

If your document contains nontrivial examples of program code, we
recommend releasing these examples in parallel under your choice of
free software license, such as the GNU General Public License, to
permit their use in free software.
